citation.article-title: Numerical and chemical classification of Actinoplanes and some related actinomycetes

p.s: Description of Actinoplanes derwentensis sp. nov.
Actinoplanes derwentensis (der. wen-ten'sis. ML adj. derwentensis, pertaining to the Derwent, a river in County Durham, UK, from which the organism was isolated)
Orange to dark orange substrate mycelium formed on modified Bennett's agar.
Spherical sporangia readily formed, spores motile and arranged irregularly within sporangia.

Degrades arbutin, casein, chitin, DNA, elastin, lecithin, RNA and starch; utilizes adonitol, L-arabinose, dextrin, D-fructose, D-galactose, D-glucose, meso-inositol, D-lactose, D-maltose, D-mannitol, D-mannose, methyl β-D-glucoside, D-sorbitol, D-xylose and sodium fumarate as sole carbon sources but not methyl α-D-glucoside, D-ribose, catechol, coumarin, m-, o- or p-hydroxybenzoic acid, syringaldehyde, syringic acid or vanillin.
The organism is tolerant to a number of antibiotics and chemical inhibitors (Table 6).
It grows at 4 and 30 °C, but not at 37 °C.
The peptidoglycan contains meso- and hydroxydiaminopimelic acid.
The principal wall sugars are arabinose, galactose, glucose, mannose and xylose.

The organism also contains complex mixtures of straight- and branched-chain fatty acids, with hexadecanoic, 14-methylpentadecanoic and 14-methylhexadecanoic acids predominating, tetrahydrogenated menaquinones with nine isoprene units as the predominant isoprenologue, and major amounts of diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylinositol.
Type strain: Actinoplanes derwentensis LA 107 (IFO 14935; NCIB 12875).
